She received her B.S. in Physical Therapy from Hunter College in 1980 and her M.A. in Community Health Education from Adelphi University in 1985. She then received her B.S. in Nursing (1994), her M.S. in Midwifery (1997), and her Doctorate of Nursing Practice (2009) from Stony Brook University. Altman is a Certified Nurse Midwife whose clinical research focuses on factors affecting midwifery utilization.   Since 2011, Altman has served as Adjunct Clinical Instructor in the School of Nursing at Stony Brook University. She has also worked in clinical settings at Beth Israel Medical Center, Bellevue Birthing Center and Hospital, and Stony Brook Midwifery Practice, where she is Assistant Clinical Professor in the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology. Altman is a board member of the National Perinatal Association and Vice President of Long Island Midwives, Inc.                                          Susan Apold   Susan Apold is Clinical Professor of Nursing. She received her B.S. in Nursing from Holy Family University in 1979. She earned her M.S. in Nursing from the University of Pennsylvania in 1982 and her Ph.D. from Adelphi University in 1992. She also earned a Certification of Advanced Practice, Adult Nurse Practitioner from the College of Mount Saint Vincent in 1996.   Apold’s scholarship focuses on advocacy for the delivery of quality, cost-effective, and accessible health care for patients in the US. She has been active in policy development and legislative and regulatory reform at both the state and national levels. Her expertise has been sought as testimony in Congressional briefings, in deliberations with private and public stakeholders during development of legislations, and by medical groups in formulating positions on the role of nurse practitioners in health care. She has also worked to increase collaboration within the field, negotiating a merger of the American Academy of Nurse Practitioners and the American College of Nurse Practitioners which resulted in the formation of the American Association of Nurse Practitioners, the largest individual member nurse practitioner organization in the country.   From 1989 to 2007, Apold was a faculty member at the College of Mount Saint Vincent. In 2008, she became the Founding Dean of the Division of Nursing and Health Studies at Concordia College and in 2011 she became the Dean of the Division of Health and Human Services for that institution. Apold is a Robert Wood Johnson Foundation Executive Nurse Fellow (2013-16) and has been a fellow of The American Academy of Nursing since 2011. In June 2014, she became a fellow of the American Academy of Nurse Practitioners.                                         Michele Crespo-Fierro   Michele Crespo-Fierro, RN, MS/MPH, AACRN, is Clinical Instructor of Nursing. She graduated cum laude with a B.S. from New York University in 1990. In 1996, she earned an M.S. in Community Health Nursing and HIV Disease and a Master of Public Health in Community Health Education from Hunter College. She anticipates receiving her Ph.D. in Nursing from CUNY Graduate Center in 2015.   Crespo-Fierro has nearly 25 years of clinical experience as a staff nurse, care coordinator, clinical nurse specialist, public health nurse, and nurse consultant. Her research interests focus on community health and HIV/AIDS, as evidenced by her dissertation, entitled “Cultural Care Needs as Shared by Puerto Rican Women Receiving HIV Care from Nurse Practitioners in New York City." In addition, she has published articles related to compliance/adherence and care management in HIV disease, certification in HIV/AIDS nursing, and supporting breast-feeding in homeless populations.   Crespo-Fierro has previously held the positions of instructor and adjunct instructor at the College of Nursing and is an active member of its community, serving as the faculty advisor to the Latinos Aspiring to Imagine Nursing Opportunities (LATINOS) student group and collaborating with Drs. Ann Kurth and Michele Shedlin on a National Institute of Health study which focuses on computerized Spanish-language counseling.                                    Selena Gilles   Selena Ann Gilles is Clinical Assistant Professor of Nursing. She earned a B.S.N. (2005) with honors, from Long Island University. She began her career as a Registered Nurse at New York Presbyterian Hospital Weill Cornell, working most of her time in the Medical Intensive Care Unit, later obtaining her critical care certification (CCRN). Dr. Gilles received her M.S.N. (2010) from Hunter Bellevue School of Nursing, and a D.N.P. (2014) from Monmouth University.   Prior to NYU, Gilles, a board certified Adult Nurse Practitioner, spent three years at New York Presbyterian Hospital Weill Cornell as an outpatient provider in the Department of Neurological Surgery. During these three years, she worked in a matrix-style environment directly with faculty and other medical professionals to identify, evaluate, and address disease prevention and health promotion issues while administering quality patient care to patients with various neurological disorders. In addition, during this time, she served as a practicum preceptor for M.S.N. students from various nursing programs, including NYU. Gilles has served as an Adjunct Clinical Instructor at NYU in the Undergraduate Nursing Program since 2010. Her program of research focuses on childhood obesity among African-American children with an emphasis on educational interventions for families that aim to decrease the epidemic.                                    Stacen Keating   Stacen Keating is Clinical Assistant Professor of Nursing. She received a B.S. in Business School Management from Binghamton University in 1988 before earning her B.S.N. from Columbia University in 1992. She then earned an M.S. from the Acute Care Nurse Practitioner Program at Northeastern University in 2000. She was awarded the Ph.D. in Nursing from the University of Pennsylvania in 2006. She was then awarded a two-year training fellowship at the Center for Health Outcomes and Policy Research, where she focused on scholarship related to the role of advanced practice nurses in improving transitional health care for elders.   Keating’s research interests include understanding the contributions of hospital nurses to patient outcomes, nursing care intensity and the consumption of nursing care by older adult patients with similar diagnoses, and education of nurses using simulation lab training. She has been invited to present her work at conferences and meetings both locally and nationally, and has published articles in Nursing and Health Sciences , the Journal of Evaluation in Clinical Practice , and the American Journal of Nursing .   Keating has been a registered nurse for nearly 15 years and has substantial clinical experience as a clinical coordinator and a staff nurse providing medical and surgical care to adult patients. Since 2008, she has held the rank of Assistant Professor in the Department of Nursing at The College of New Jersey.                                         Robin Toft Klar   Robin Toft Klar is Clinical Assistant Professor of Nursing. She received a Diploma in Nursing from Worcester City Hospital School of Nursing in 1975. She earned her B.S. in Nursing from Fitchburg State College in 1979 and an M.S. in Community Health Nursing in 1980 from Boston College. She earned her Doctor of Nursing Science degree in 2002 from Yale University School of Nursing and completed a post-doctoral fellowship at Case Western Reserve University School of Nursing in 2011-12 with a focus on global health.   Klar’s clinical research interests include improving individuals’ health with a strong public health model, particularly in global contexts. Most recently, she has been engaged in research and clinical practice both in Ghana and with Ghanaian immigrants in Worcester, Massachusetts, which has the largest expatriate Ghanaian population outside of Ghana. Investigations of the intersections of health behavior practices amongst expatriate and native Ghanaians have informed client populations and health care providers on both shores. She has been an invited presenter at regional policy and research groups and has recent publications in Health Care for Women International and Worcester Medicine .   Klar has served as a faculty member since 2000, first at Fitchburg State College (2000-2003) and then at the University of Massachusetts, Worcester (2003-2014). She received the Interprofessional Educational Achievement Award in 2009.                                    Beth Latimer   Beth Latimer, DNP, APRN-BC, is Clinical Assistant Professor of Nursing. She received her B.S. in Nursing from the University of Pennsylvania in 1985. Subsequently, she earned her M.A. in Geriatric Nursing and Nursing Administration (1993) and Doctor of Nursing Practice (2011) degrees from New York University. While a student at NYU, she received several awards including the Master’s Student Achievement Award (1992), the Dean’s Student Research Award (2010), and the Brookdale Foundation Scholarship Award (2011).   Latimer has taught in an adjunct faculty capacity at NYU for more than 20 years as a clinical instructor, preceptor, and instructor in the Clinical Simulation Learning Center. She is also active in service to the College; she has participated in the NYU3T Interprofessional Clinical Simulation at the NYSIM Center at Bellevue in 2011, the NYU Elder Care Program Health Fair in 2012 and the NYU3T Interprofessional Clinical Simulation at the College of Nursing in 2012. She has mentored graduate students as well in her capacity as a DNP Capstone Committee member. Latimer is board-certified as a Gerontological Nurse Practitioner and her clinical research focuses on issues related to elder care.                                    Janet Standard   Janet Standard, DNP-NPP, APRN-BC, is Clinical Assistant Professor of Nursing. She received a B.A. in 1976 from Kenyon College before earning both her B.S. in Nursing and M.S. in Nursing degrees from Columbia University in 1982 and 1988, respectively. She earned the Doctor of Nursing Practice degree in Psychiatric Clinical Leadership from the NYU College of Nursing in 2011. She also holds a graduate certificate in holistic nursing.   Standard’s doctoral research focused on stress reduction in college students using mindfulness meditation. She is a board-certified Adult Psychiatric Nurse Practitioner and she has more than twenty years of clinical experience in psychiatric nursing. Since 2008, Standard has practiced at the NYU Student Health Center and has served as member of the Mindfulness Team, working on new and innovative stress reduction and relaxation programs for students and staff at NYU. She also served as a member of the Gender Team, which worked to develop a comprehensive program to serve the medical and counseling needs of the University’s transgender population, as well as the Eating Disorders Team and the Trauma Team. She has taught courses at the NYU College of Nursing in an adjunct faculty capacity since 2011 and was named Preceptor of the Year in Psychiatric Nursing in 2012.                                         James Weidel   James Weidel is Clinical Assistant Professor of Nursing. He received his B.S. in Nursing from D’Youville College in 1998. He earned his M.S. in Nursing as a Family Nurse Practitioner from the Medical University of South Carolina in 2007 and his Ph.D. from the University of Miami in 2013. He also earned a Post-Masters Certificate as a Psychiatric Mental Health Nurse Practitioner from the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences in May 2014.   Weidel’s clinical research interests include impulsive decision-making, risk behavior, and adolescent substance abuse. To date, he has published four related articles and one book chapter and he has presented his work at seven regional conferences. Weidel is a board certified advanced practice registered nurse and a licensed family nurse practitioner. He has 16 years of diverse clinical experience as a staff nurse, travel nurse, and family nurse practitioner.   Weidel served as a clinical instructor and teaching assistant at the University of Miami School of Nursing and Health Studies (2007-2012) and a member of Florida International University’s adjunct faculty in the School of Nursing and Health Sciences (2011-2013). He has taught courses in Psychiatric/Mental Health Nursing, Special Populations, Adult Health, and Family Health. To advocate for the growth and development of its members as leaders in nursing and in society through education, outreach, advocacy, and service.   To promote cultural understanding and appreciation of the contributions and importance of Latino nurses.   To promote cultural enrichment, diversity, and discovery by educating LATINOS nursing members and the community.       2014-2015 Executive Board                    President   Joanna Camacho   jc4591@nyu.edu       Vice President   Jessica Arzola   ja2349@nyu.edu       Treasurer/ UNSO Rep   Sarah DeLeno   smd485@nyu.edu       Secretary   Darlene Adames   da1491@nyu.edu       Traditional Sophomore Rep   Mildres Aguirre   ma3274@nyu.edu       Traditional Junior Rep   Karla Alvizures   kma376@nyu.edu       Traditional Senior Rep   Mariel Hernandez   mvh241@nyu.edu       Event Planner   Alyssa Diaz   ad2402@nyu.edu       Faculty Advisor   Michele Crespo-Fierro   mc96@nyu.edu                                                                                                                                  Student Organizations            Doctoral Student Organization   Advanced Nursing Student Organization   Undergraduate Nursing Student Organization   Asian Pacific Islander Nursing Student Association   Black Student Nurses Association   Geriatric Student Interest Group   LATINOS   LGBTQ-FANSS   Men Entering Nursing   Nursing Students for Global Health   Pediatric Nursing Student Association   Women's Health Student Nursing Association                            Back to top                                                    Contact   Academic Bulletin   Open Positions   Site Map   NYU College of Dentistry   Legal   Site Credits

Altman is a board member of the National Perinatal Association and Vice President of Long Island Midwives, Inc.                                          Susan Apold   Susan Apold is Clinical Professor of Nursing. She received her B.S. in Nursing from Holy Family University in 1979. She earned her M.S. in Nursing from the University of Pennsylvania in 1982 and her Ph.D. from Adelphi University in 1992. She also earned a Certification of Advanced Practice, Adult Nurse Practitioner from the College of Mount Saint Vincent in 1996.   Apold’s scholarship focuses on advocacy for the delivery of quality, cost-effective, and accessible health care for patients in the US. She has been active in policy development and legislative and regulatory reform at both the state and national levels. Her expertise has been sought as testimony in Congressional briefings, in deliberations with private and public stakeholders during development of legislations, and by medical groups in formulating positions on the role of nurse practitioners in health care. She has also worked to increase collaboration within the field, negotiating a merger of the American Academy of Nurse Practitioners and the American College of Nurse Practitioners which resulted in the formation of the American Association of Nurse Practitioners, the largest individual member nurse practitioner organization in the country.   From 1989 to 2007, Apold was a faculty member at the College of Mount Saint Vincent. In 2008, she became the Founding Dean of the Division of Nursing and Health Studies at Concordia College and in 2011 she became the Dean of the Division of Health and Human Services for that institution. Apold is a Robert Wood Johnson Foundation Executive Nurse Fellow (2013-16) and has been a fellow of The American Academy of Nursing since 2011. In June 2014, she became a fellow of the American Academy of Nurse Practitioners.                                         Michele Crespo-Fierro   Michele Crespo-Fierro, RN, MS/MPH, AACRN, is Clinical Instructor of Nursing. She graduated cum laude with a B.S. from New York University in 1990. In 1996, she earned an M.S. in Community Health Nursing and HIV Disease and a Master of Public Health in Community Health Education from Hunter College. She anticipates receiving her Ph.D. in Nursing from CUNY Graduate Center in 2015.   Crespo-Fierro has nearly 25 years of clinical experience as a staff nurse, care coordinator, clinical nurse specialist, public health nurse, and nurse consultant. Her research interests focus on community health and HIV/AIDS, as evidenced by her dissertation, entitled “Cultural Care Needs as Shared by Puerto Rican Women Receiving HIV Care from Nurse Practitioners in New York City." In addition, she has published articles related to compliance/adherence and care management in HIV disease, certification in HIV/AIDS nursing, and supporting breast-feeding in homeless populations.   Crespo-Fierro has previously held the positions of instructor and adjunct instructor at the College of Nursing and is an active member of its community, serving as the faculty advisor to the Latinos Aspiring to Imagine Nursing Opportunities (LATINOS) student group and collaborating with Drs. Ann Kurth and Michele Shedlin on a National Institute of Health study which focuses on computerized Spanish-language counseling.                                    Selena Gilles   Selena Ann Gilles is Clinical Assistant Professor of Nursing. She earned a B.S.N. (2005) with honors, from Long Island University. She began her career as a Registered Nurse at New York Presbyterian Hospital Weill Cornell, working most of her time in the Medical Intensive Care Unit, later obtaining her critical care certification (CCRN). Dr. Gilles received her M.S.N. (2010) from Hunter Bellevue School of Nursing, and a D.N.P. (2014) from Monmouth University.   Prior to NYU, Gilles, a board certified Adult Nurse Practitioner, spent three years at New York Presbyterian Hospital Weill Cornell as an outpatient provider in the Department of Neurological Surgery. During these three years, she worked in a matrix-style environment directly with faculty and other medical professionals to identify, evaluate, and address disease prevention and health promotion issues while administering quality patient care to patients with various neurological disorders. In addition, during this time, she served as a practicum preceptor for M.S.N. students from various nursing programs, including NYU. Gilles has served as an Adjunct Clinical Instructor at NYU in the Undergraduate Nursing Program since 2010. Her program of research focuses on childhood obesity among African-American children with an emphasis on educational interventions for families that aim to decrease the epidemic.                                    Stacen Keating   Stacen Keating is Clinical Assistant Professor of Nursing. She received a B.S. in Business School Management from Binghamton University in 1988 before earning her B.S.N. from Columbia University in 1992. She then earned an M.S. from the Acute Care Nurse Practitioner Program at Northeastern University in 2000. She was awarded the Ph.D. in Nursing from the University of Pennsylvania in 2006. She was then awarded a two-year training fellowship at the Center for Health Outcomes and Policy Research, where she focused on scholarship related to the role of advanced practice nurses in improving transitional health care for elders.   Keating’s research interests include understanding the contributions of hospital nurses to patient outcomes, nursing care intensity and the consumption of nursing care by older adult patients with similar diagnoses, and education of nurses using simulation lab training. She has been invited to present her work at conferences and meetings both locally and nationally, and has published articles in Nursing and Health Sciences , the Journal of Evaluation in Clinical Practice , and the American Journal of Nursing .   Keating has been a registered nurse for nearly 15 years and has substantial clinical experience as a clinical coordinator and a staff nurse providing medical and surgical care to adult patients. Since 2008, she has held the rank of Assistant Professor in the Department of Nursing at The College of New Jersey.                                         Robin Toft Klar   Robin Toft Klar is Clinical Assistant Professor of Nursing. She received a Diploma in Nursing from Worcester City Hospital School of Nursing in 1975. She earned her B.S. in Nursing from Fitchburg State College in 1979 and an M.S. in Community Health Nursing in 1980 from Boston College. She earned her Doctor of Nursing Science degree in 2002 from Yale University School of Nursing and completed a post-doctoral fellowship at Case Western Reserve University School of Nursing in 2011-12 with a focus on global health.   Klar’s clinical research interests include improving individuals’ health with a strong public health model, particularly in global contexts. Most recently, she has been engaged in research and clinical practice both in Ghana and with Ghanaian immigrants in Worcester, Massachusetts, which has the largest expatriate Ghanaian population outside of Ghana. Investigations of the intersections of health behavior practices amongst expatriate and native Ghanaians have informed client populations and health care providers on both shores. She has been an invited presenter at regional policy and research groups and has recent publications in Health Care for Women International and Worcester Medicine .   Klar has served as a faculty member since 2000, first at Fitchburg State College (2000-2003) and then at the University of Massachusetts, Worcester (2003-2014). She received the Interprofessional Educational Achievement Award in 2009.                                    Beth Latimer   Beth Latimer, DNP, APRN-BC, is Clinical Assistant Professor of Nursing. She received her B.S. in Nursing from the University of Pennsylvania in 1985. Subsequently, she earned her M.A. in Geriatric Nursing and Nursing Administration (1993) and Doctor of Nursing Practice (2011) degrees from New York University. While a student at NYU, she received several awards including the Master’s Student Achievement Award (1992), the Dean’s Student Research Award (2010), and the Brookdale Foundation Scholarship Award (2011).   Latimer has taught in an adjunct faculty capacity at NYU for more than 20 years as a clinical instructor, preceptor, and instructor in the Clinical Simulation Learning Center. She is also active in service to the College; she has participated in the NYU3T Interprofessional Clinical Simulation at the NYSIM Center at Bellevue in 2011, the NYU Elder Care Program Health Fair in 2012 and the NYU3T Interprofessional Clinical Simulation at the College of Nursing in 2012. She has mentored graduate students as well in her capacity as a DNP Capstone Committee member. Latimer is board-certified as a Gerontological Nurse Practitioner and her clinical research focuses on issues related to elder care.                                    Janet Standard   Janet Standard, DNP-NPP, APRN-BC, is Clinical Assistant Professor of Nursing. She received a B.A. in 1976 from Kenyon College before earning both her B.S. in Nursing and M.S. in Nursing degrees from Columbia University in 1982 and 1988, respectively. She earned the Doctor of Nursing Practice degree in Psychiatric Clinical Leadership from the NYU College of Nursing in 2011. She also holds a graduate certificate in holistic nursing.   Standard’s doctoral research focused on stress reduction in college students using mindfulness meditation. She is a board-certified Adult Psychiatric Nurse Practitioner and she has more than twenty years of clinical experience in psychiatric nursing. Since 2008, Standard has practiced at the NYU Student Health Center and has served as member of the Mindfulness Team, working on new and innovative stress reduction and relaxation programs for students and staff at NYU. She also served as a member of the Gender Team, which worked to develop a comprehensive program to serve the medical and counseling needs of the University’s transgender population, as well as the Eating Disorders Team and the Trauma Team. She has taught courses at the NYU College of Nursing in an adjunct faculty capacity since 2011 and was named Preceptor of the Year in Psychiatric Nursing in 2012.                                         James Weidel   James Weidel is Clinical Assistant Professor of Nursing. He received his B.S. in Nursing from D’Youville College in 1998. He earned his M.S. in Nursing as a Family Nurse Practitioner from the Medical University of South Carolina in 2007 and his Ph.D. from the University of Miami in 2013. He also earned a Post-Masters Certificate as a Psychiatric Mental Health Nurse Practitioner from the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences in May 2014.   Weidel’s clinical research interests include impulsive decision-making, risk behavior, and adolescent substance abuse. To date, he has published four related articles and one book chapter and he has presented his work at seven regional conferences. Weidel is a board certified advanced practice registered nurse and a licensed family nurse practitioner. He has 16 years of diverse clinical experience as a staff nurse, travel nurse, and family nurse practitioner.   Weidel served as a clinical instructor and teaching assistant at the University of Miami School of Nursing and Health Studies (2007-2012) and a member of Florida International University’s adjunct faculty in the School of Nursing and Health Sciences (2011-2013). He has taught courses in Psychiatric/Mental Health Nursing, Special Populations, Adult Health, and Family Health. To promote cultural understanding and appreciation of the contributions and importance of Latino nurses.
